environmental_bioconcentrations.References: (1) USEPA/OPP; Reregistration Eligibility Decisions (REDs) Database. Butylate. EPA 738-F-93-014. Sept 1993. Available from, as of June 27, 2018: https://iaspub.epa.gov/apex/pesticides/f?p=chemicalsearch:1 (2) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994)
environmental_bioconcentrations.Value: Bioconcentration factors of 180 for edible tissues, 630 for nonedible tissues, and 410 for whole fish using bluegill sunfish continuously exposed to 14C-butylate at 0.12-0.16 ppm(1). According to a classification scheme(2), this BCF suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is high(SRC). By day 14 of the depuration period, 98-99% of 14C-butylate residues were eliminated from the fish tissues(1).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) Bean BW et al; Weed Sci 36: 70-7 (1988) (2) Obrigawitch T et al; Weed Sci 31: 187-92 (1983) (3) Tuxhorn GL et al; Weed Sci 34: 961-5 (1986) (4) Skipper HD et al; Weed Sci 34: 558-63 (1986) (5) USEPA/OPP; Reregistration Eligibility Decisions (REDs) Database. Butylate. EPA 738-F-93-014. Sept 1993. Available from, as of June 27, 2018: https://iaspub.epa.gov/apex/pesticides/f?p=chemicalsearch:1 (6) MacBean C, ed; e-Pesticide Manual. 15th ed., ver. 5.1, Alton, UK: British Crop Protection Council. Butylate (2008-41-5) (2008-2010)
environmental_biodegradations.Value: AEROBIC: In field and laboratory studies, butylate was shown to degrade at accelerated rates in soil after an initial application to a previously untreated soil(1,2); the accelerated degradation may be due to microbial adaptation(SRC). Dissipation of butylate was more than twice as fast in a nonautoclaved soil as compared to the autoclaved soil suggesting a microbial route of degradation(3); butylate sulfoxide was thought to be the microbial metabolite(3); dissipation other than microbial was probably from volatilization(3). Under laboratory conditions, 14C-radiolabeled butylate was degraded more rapidly to 14-C carbon dioxide in soils that had prior exposure to butylate than in soils having no prior exposure(4); over a 36-day incubation period, roughly 18-35% of the 14-C butylate applied to these soils degraded to 14-C carbon dioxide(4). Butylate degraded with a reported half-life of 24 days in sandy loam soil that was incubated for 245 days in darkness at 24 °C(1). The decline in butylate soil residues is due primarily to volatilization (47%) with aerobic soil metabolism of secondary importance(5). In soil, microbial degradation involves hydrolysis to ethylmercaptan, diisobutylamine and carbon dioxide; the half-life is 1.5-10 weeks(6).

environmental_biodegradations.References: (1) USEPA/OPP; Reregistration Eligibility Decisions (REDs) Database. Butylate. EPA 738-F-93-014. Sept 1993. Available from, as of June 27, 2018: https://iaspub.epa.gov/apex/pesticides/f?p=chemicalsearch:1
environmental_biodegradations.Value: ANAEROBIC: Butylate degraded with a reported half-life of 64 days in anaerobic (flooding plus nitrogen atmosphere) sandy loam soil that was incubated in the dark at 24 °C for up to 60 days following 20 days of aerobic incubation(1).

logP.References: Hansch, C., Leo, A., D. Hoekman. Exploring QSAR - Hydrophobic, Electronic, and Steric Constants. Washington, DC: American Chemical Society., 1995., p. 92

mechanism_of_action.Value: Inhibition of lipid synthesis- not ACCase inhibition.

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Krapac IG et al; J Soil Contam 4: 209-226 (1995)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SOIL: The average and range of butylate at agrichemical facilities in Illinois was 639 ug/kg and 40-460,000 ug/kg, respectively(1).

soil_absorption_mobility.References: (1) Weidner CW; Degradation in Groundwater and Mobility of Herbicides. OWRT-A-O24-NEB (NTIS PB-239 242/1st) Washington,DC: Off Water Res Technol p. 52 (1974) (2) Wauchope RD et al; Rev Environ Contam Toxicol 123: 1-35 (1991) (3) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 23 (1983) (4) Trevisan M et al; Sci Total Environ 123/124: 531-9 (1992) (5) Ekler Z et al; Kolloidkem Konf Eloadasai 3: 57-60 (1981) (6) USEPA/OPP; Reregistration Eligibility Decisions (REDs) Database. Butylate. EPA 738-F-93-014. Sept 1993. Available from, as of June 27, 2018: https://iaspub.epa.gov/apex/pesticides/f?p=chemicalsearch:1
soil_absorption_mobility.Value: Based upon experimental adsorption measurements in a silty clay loam soil and a sandy loam soil(1), the Koc of butylate can be calculated to range from 185 to 260(SRC). The US Dept of Agric's Pesticide Properties Database lists a Koc value of 400 for butylate(2). According to a classification scheme(3), these experimental Koc values suggest that butylate is expected to have moderate mobility in soil(SRC). In one soil column leaching study using three different soil types, most of the initially added butylate remained in the upper 4 in of soil with no butylate leaching below 8 in(1). In a 100-day field study (in silt loam and clay loam soils), butylate was found to have a low mobility as only very small quantities were leached to depth of 45-60 cm(4). Adsorption of butylate has been found to increase as the content of organic matter and clay increases, with a corresponding decrease in leaching(1,5). Based on batch equilibrium experiments, butylate was determined to be mobile to moderately mobile in Keeton sandy loam, Columbia loamy sand, Sorrento loam, and Atterberry silt loam soils(6). The adsorption Freundlich values reported for these soils were 1.5, 4.8, 7.3, and 5.5, respectively(6).

plant_translocations.content: Injury to corn (Zea mays L.) from S-ethyl diisobutylthiocarbamate (butylate) was investigated with respect to hybrid. Field experiments in 1971 at Dillon and Clemson, South Carolina, established that the corn hybrid ‘Coker 71’ was more tolerant to butylate than ‘Pioneer 511A’. Also established as being tolerant and sensitive to butylate were the hybrids ‘Pioneer 3030’ and ‘PAG 644’, respectively. Laboratory studies with 14C-butylate showed that the resistant hybrid ‘Pioneer 3030’ took up less 14C-butylate and metabolized more to 14CO2 than did ‘PAG 644’.
plant_translocations.reference: Wright, T. H., & Rieck, C. E. (1973). Differential butylate injury to corn hybrids. Weed science, 21(3), 194-196.

method.Apply Location: Laboratory - Root application in sand-water system
method.Plant Grown Condition: grown in vermiculite at 24°C, later transferred to sand-water system
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: 100 ppm butylate solution for uptake studies; 1.5 μCi 14C-butylate applied to sand-water system
method.Other Information: 6 replicate plants used for 14C uptake/translocation study
